The agency I work for has open-sourced/soft-lunched https://github.com/salsadigitalauorg/merlin-framework which is a CMS-agnostic, any-to-any migration framework ...we've used it to migrate many projects to GovCMS (but unfortunately I wasn't involved in these migration projects, so don't know how to use it :sweat_smile: ) ...I thought that it might be of use to others.

salsadigitalauorg/merlin-framework
Merlin - The Migration Wizard. Contribute to salsadigitalauorg/merlin-framework development by creating an account on GitHub.

Merlin Framework provides a standardised method for migrating content from a website (markup) to more structured data.

This allows for simplified migration of web content to a new CMS or other systems.
...I think that it roughly works by parsing a website and then creating db records based on a .yml configuration.
Interesting tool. It seems to grab publicly available content and re-structures it based on configuration (mappings based on Xpath). And it seems to ship with a crawler to automatically collect urls.
Yup, that's how it works. The framework/API is what we've open-sourced; there's also a GUI in the works, but I think that one will be kept proprietary.
What was the use case @klonos ? Were there gov websites where they didn't have access to db?
Old/legacy gov sites built in things that do not have a migration path to Drupal (even plain HTML sites).

...there was also a requirement for close-to-zero downtime. They'd run the script multiple times until they were happy with the result, then they'd place a small content freeze and port to Drupal (GovCMS) ...as opposed to placing the content freeze for the entirety of the migration.

...a bit of more info on Merlin from the main developer involved in its development:

It’s a soft launch as there are still a few things we’re hoping to clean up (namely around docs/onboarding) and a couple bugs to squash. ...Merlin was built first and foremost to help make migrations from legacy CMS (or any website) to Drupal easier. It crawls and scrapes content and creates structured json ready for import via migrate api.

It’s got support for menus, taxonomy, content, paragraphs (incl. reusable paragraphs via library), media, linkit url rewriting, media, and plenty more. It’s also generic by nature, so can be used for migrations to Wordpress, or to create structured data for any other purpose (e.g ecommerce competitive pricing analysis, static site exporter, 404 link checker across sites)..

We’ll aim to launch a blog series of how-to guides that help explain all the use cases, it’s still early days and an evolving tool but hopefully it’ll become a go-to when people think about content migration.

docs: https://salsadigitalauorg.github.io/merlin-framework/docs/getting-started

Getting Started · Merlin
<p>Merlin Framework provides a standardised method for migrating content from a website (markup) to more structured data.</p>

I want to add a form_alter hook in core. Is the .module file of a module the recommended place for such hooks to live in, or the .admin.inc file?

@klonos I think it depends on the change you're wanting to add... If you're adding one or more new form fields/elements, then maybe .admin.inc. If it's just a simple change like adding a JS file for processing or changing a value, then maybe .module.

It's the later. ...is there any documentation on that? ...I am also wondering things like where the new hook function should go within the file? ...do we try to list functions alphabetically? ...do we add them based on co-relation?
Hmm, not sure any of that's really documented...
thought so :sweat_smile: ...just looking for some sanity ...my OCDs start kicking in, and I start to twitch :slight_smile:

I try to keep all hook_* and *_alter functions in .module files and put other code that can be grouped together functionality-wise in *.inc files. Then I'm not confused when something is happening, and I can't find the code for it.

We generally put hooks in the module file, since you cant be sure if other files are loaded at all times, in which case the hook wouldnt fire. If you put it in an inc file, youd need a include_once or such in the module file.
I made the assumption that that would be done, but I should have been explicit, and you're right, without including the file, the hook won't get triggered.
That's great info. Can we capture all that in our documentation somewhere?
